name: Glossopharyngeal Neuralgia with Concurrent Eagle Syndrome
chief_complaint: Severe, stabbing pain in my throat and ear, especially when swallowing or turning my head.
symptoms: Triggered by swallowing, coughing, or head movement
physical_findings: Exquisitely tender styloid process on palpation
No cranial nerve deficits on exam

lab_results.MRI brain: No vascular compression of cranial nerves IX/X

prognosis: Variable - medical management successful in ~60% cases, surgical intervention has high success rate but carries risks of cranial nerve injury
description: A rare pain syndrome combining features of glossopharyngeal neuralgia (cranial nerve IX irritation) and Eagle syndrome (mechanical compression from elongated styloid process). The dual pathology creates severe neuropathic and mechanical pain with potential for dangerous vagal responses.
multiple_choice: Glossopharyngeal Neuralgia with Concurrent Eagle Syndrome
